text: as fear continues to spread over the
impact of the Greek debt crisis more
people are questioning how such a small
country could impact markets around the
world
we asked New York Times reporters Graham
bully and Nelson Schwartz to explain the
origins of the crisis its impact in the
US and abroad the markets response to
Europe's rescue package and what to look
for next Greece may be small and he's
one of the smallest countries in the EU
but it has a lot of debt mountains of
debt which it tried to conceal them
which it has built up over the years
and that debt is owned by banks in other
countries to a large extent so for
example Greece owes to Portugal Portugal
owes to Spain Spain owes a lot to
Germany France the United States so you
have a domino effect and that was a big
worry and one of one of the big worries
that led to the bailout these worries
impact investors in the u.s. I think it
comes down to two two things first just
confidence and stability in the overall
financial markets and then in particular
worries about the banks so American
banks just as European banks owned lots
of Greek debt
so if Greek a Greece was to default on
its debt that would send ripples into
the American system as well which would
be quite important also ripples through
the German banks and through the
European banking system into the US so
again if there's anxiety about European
banks that's gonna spread to American
banks and the American stock market
while Greece enjoyed the benefits of EU
membership for many years it now finds
itself boxed in if a country were not in
the Euro there'll be three ways to get
out of this problem
grow grow your way out of the problem in
a strong economic growth pay back your
debts
- you could devalue currency and you see
that all the time in emerging markets if
you had that freedom and three default
so it doesn't have that pressure valve I
think there's a fear of a default of
Greece might have on
imaginable or unforeseeable shall we say
consequences sort of like Lehman did and
nobody wants to go there the crisis has
invigorated critics of the European
Union there are a lot of good things
about the EU you know it was formed 50
years ago and it's produced many great
things peace its original intention
across the continent economic prosperity
it's become a very valuable trading zone
so for example let's say you're a French
or German automaker you want to have
operations in Slovakia which is a euro
using country it's just much easier and
that bet those trade and employment
benefits have really helped Europe grow
a bit in the last ten years the problem
is it's so diverse and you have
countries like Germany very big with its
own needs smaller countries like Greece
countries on the periphery and it's been
hard to fit everybody into the same
economic straightjacket in Greece calls
for spending cuts were followed by riots
some financial experts agree with the
protesters views there's a fine dividing
line I think between making sure Greece
cuts back its spending and reduces its
debt and doing that too much which sends
the country into decline and the kind of
a downward spiral and no one including
in the United States wants to give up
benefits and early retirement or
pensions that kind of thing and there's
tremendous political opposition to it
plus the economy there's pretty weak and
no one wants to have spending cuts in
the middle of a recession Europe has
pledged nearly a trillion dollars but
the crisis is still not contained
markets were initially you know calm by
that but they've started to question the
credibility of it and they still want to
see one how will this work you know will
the money actually put up when push
comes to shove they still haven't seen
as one trader told me the color of the
money - perhaps more broadly what impact
will it have on the economies so the
other side of this program is that
Greece and other countries have promised
fiscal austerity
would be necessary to contain it is a
real belief that the countries are
serious about the austerity measures
they've committed to if material
concrete steps are taken I think that
would reassure the markets simply
borrowing the money and throwing it at
it if there are an underlying reforms
it's just going to kick the can down the
road what should we be watching for next
you're going to see if this one trillion
dollar bailout package is put into
effect you're going to see debt
transferred essentially from the weaker
members of the euro zone like Greece
Spain Italy and you know on the
periphery to the stronger members like
Germany and France and that's going to
build tensions because people in Germany
and in France don't want to bail out
other other Europeans they feel like
they should be responsible for their own
financial affairs there's still not the
fiscal centrality and the willingness to
to move funds around the continent to
support regions in trouble that there is
in the US for example so what we might
see from this is a greater momentum
toward that so perhaps we will see it's
going to be very politically difficult
there are still lots of opposition
amongst the European countries to
sharing power with each other but this
might be the push that sets Europe
toward that
